choices.C: Add the product's IP addresses to your organization's SPF record.
choices.B: Allowlist the IP addresses of the third-party filtering product.
choices.D: List the IP addresses of the product as an Inbound Gateway.
choices.A: Add the product's IP addresses as an approved sender.

questions.question_text: Your organization uses a third-party product to filter mail before it arrives at your Workspace Domain. How should you configure Gmail to ensure that inbound messages are not seen as a spam attack due to the volume of mail being received from this product?

discussion.content:
Answer C
"If you send mail with other servers or third-party services in addition to Google Workspace, create a custom SPF record that authorizes these senders."
https://apps.google.com/supportwidget/articlehome?hl=en&article_url=https%3A%2F%2Fsupport.google.com%2Fa%2Fanswer%2F10685031%3Fhl%3Den&assistant_id=generic-unu&product_context=10685031&product_name=UnuFlow&trigger_context=a

Selected Answer: D
D. List the IP addresses of the product as an Inbound Gateway.

Selected Answer: D
Such third-party product should exactely be added as an Inbound Gateway (it is what it is) to improve spam detection, and never in Approved IP whitelist / Sender

Selected Answer: D
https://support.google.com/a/answer/60730?hl=en

Selected Answer: D
D is correct, 
ensure that inbound messages from the third-party product, which filters mail before it arrives at your Google Workspace domain, are not seen as a spam attack due to the volume of mail being received, you should list the IP addresses of the product as an Inbound Gateway in Google Workspace

choices.D: Install the Google Endpoint Verification extension on machines using Drive for Desktop.
choices.C: Apps > Google Workspace > Drive and Docs > Features and Applications > Google Drive for Desktop > Only Allow Google Drive for desktop on authorized devices
choices.B: Devices > Endpoints > Add a filter > Management Type > Drive for desktop > Apply
choices.E: Create a company-owned device inventory using serial numbers of devices.
choices.A: Create a company-owned device inventory using an asset tag.

questions.question_text: Your organization is in the process of deploying Google Drive for desktop so that your users can access Drive files directly from their desktops. For security reasons, you want to restrict Drive for desktop to only company-owned devices. What two steps should you take from the admin panel to restrict Drive for desktop to only company-owned devices? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
C and E
https://support.google.com/a/answer/9299541?hl=en

Selected Answer: CE
C. Apps > Google Workspace > Drive and Docs > Features and Applications > Google Drive for Desktop > Only Allow Google Drive for desktop on authorized devices.
E. Create a company-owned device inventory using serial numbers of devices.

Selected Answer: CE
Vote CE.
Opt C path changed to Apps > Google Workspace > Settings for Drive and Docs > Google Drive for desktop > Only Allow Google Drive for desktop on authorized devices.
A: No. An asset tag has nothing to do with Google Drive for desktop.
B: No. The current path shall be Devices > Mobile & endpoints > Devices > Add a filter > Type > (One of desktop) but this only for selection, and only actions you can do are either “SIGN OUT USER” or “DELETE DEVICES”, which only deal with joined devices, not prevent the future joining devices.
D: No. Installing GEV does not need Drive for Desktop
https://cloud.google.com/endpoint-verification/docs/self-install-extension
https://support.google.com/a/answer/9299541?hl=en

Selected Answer: CE
C - enable the feature to only allow Drive for Desktop installation on authorized devices (which are company-owned devices)
E - create a list of company owned devices with serial number

comments.content: I was wrong the answer should be CE

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
BC is correct, 
B. Devices > Endpoints > Add a filter > Management Type > Drive for desktop > Apply:
This step involves creating a filter in the Google Workspace admin console to target devices that are using Google Drive for desktop. By applying this filter, you can identify and manage devices specifically using the Google Drive for desktop application.

C. Apps > Google Workspace > Drive and Docs > Features and Applications > Google Drive for Desktop > Only Allow Google Drive for desktop on authorized devices:
In this step, you can configure the Google Drive for Desktop application to be allowed only on authorized devices. By enabling this setting, Google Drive for desktop will be restricted to run only on company-owned devices that meet the specified authorization criteria.

Selected Answer: CE
Just as a detail the route for this configuration in console, recently changed (but doesnt affect that this is the correct answer)

choices.B: Create a shared drive for the non-confidential files, give the HR team manager access, and give contributor access to the entire organization.
choices.C: Create a shared drive for non-confidential files, give the HR team content manager access, and give view access to the organization.
choices.A: Have the HR lead create a folder in their MyDrive for the non-confidential files, give edit access to the HR team, and give view access to the organization.
choices.D: Create a shared drive for all files, give the HR team content manager access, and give view access to the organization.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. Create a shared drive for non-confidential files, give the HR team content manager access, and give view access to the organization.

Selected Answer: C
C is the answer as D gives access to all files - including confidential ones

questions.question_text: Your organization implemented Single Sign-On (SSO) for the multiple cloud-based services it uses. During authentication, one service indicates that access to the SSO provider is not possible due to invalid information. What should you do?

choices.C: Open Admin Console > Security > Less Secure Apps.
choices.B: Open Admin Console > Security > API Controls > App Access Control > Manage Google Services.
choices.D: Open Admin Console > Security > API Controls > App Access Control > Settings.
choices.A: Open Admin Console > Security > API Controls > App Access Control > Manage Third Party App Access.
